intro: Trichocline peruviana, commonly known as the Peruvian trichocline, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbel-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in high-altitude environments, often in rocky or mountainous terrain. Its botanical features include a slender stem and small, white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. Trichocline peruviana is of interest to botanists due to its unique adaptations to high-altitude conditions.
